content: More than 53,000 commercial vessels travel the world's waters, regulated by international protocols and U.S. laws to prevent pollution. Concerns exist about enforcement adequacy and environmental impacts, especially in the cruise industry. The cruise industry, representing 13% of the world shipping fleet, is a significant contributor to the U.S. economy, generating $40 billion in benefits and 357,000 jobs in 2009. With a fleet of over 230 ships, the industry has seen a 7.4% annual growth in passengers since 1990, hosting 14.3 million passengers in 2010. The environmental impacts of cruise activities have raised concerns despite its economic contributions. The worldwide cruise industry has seen significant growth since 1990, with an average annual growth rate of 7.4%. In 2010, cruises hosted 14.3 million passengers on over 230 ships, majority of which are foreign-flagged. The industry continues to add larger, more luxurious ships, with the average ship size increasing every five years. Safety and health concerns are key issues for the industry. The cruise ship industry faces safety and health concerns due to the large volume of waste generated on board. A typical one-week voyage on a large cruise ship with 3,000 passengers and crew can produce 210,000 gallons of sewage, 1 million gallons of graywater, 130 gallons of hazardous waste, 8 tons of solid waste, and 25,000 gallons of oily bilge water. Proper treatment and disposal of these wastes are essential to prevent risks to human health and the environment. The cruise ship industry generates a large volume of waste, including sewage, graywater, hazardous wastes, solid waste, and oily bilge water. Improper disposal of these wastes can pose risks to human health and the environment. Concerns have been raised about the adequacy of laws for managing these wastes, with weak enforcement noted. Foreign-flag cruise ships have been involved in numerous illegal discharge cases in U.S. waters, as highlighted in a 2000 General Accounting Office report. The General Accounting Office (GAO) reviewed illegal discharge cases in U.S. waters, finding that 83% involved oil or oil-based products. 72% of the discharges were accidental, 15% intentional, and 13% undetermined. Cruise ships accounted for 4% of the 2,400 illegal discharge cases by foreign-flag ships.
